scenario_draft.scenario: The Culinary Bootcamp Keepsake Swap: Decision at Registration

participants.name: You
participants.profile: Aspiring restaurateur attending a weekend culinary bootcamp

participants.name: Bob
participants.profile: Aspiring restaurateur attending a weekend culinary bootcamp

behavior_choices.keep_item: Keep the kitchen starter kit you received at registration, which contains a chef's apron in a unique color.
behavior_choices.trade_item: Trade your kitchen starter kit (with the unique apron) for Bob's starter kit, which contains a chef's hat with a custom embroidered patch.

scenario_draft.description: At check-in for a weekend culinary bootcamp, each participant receives a sealed kitchen starter kit as a welcome gift. Your kit contains a high-quality chef's apron in a distinctive color, while Bob's kit contains a professional chef's hat featuring a custom embroidered patch. Shortly after registration, the bootcamp coordinator announces a lighthearted icebreaker: you and Bob are invited to swap your unopened kits if you wish, or simply keep your own. The swap is completely optional, and neither item will be used during the bootcamp (all attire and tools are provided separately for training). The only impact of your decision is which commemorative item you will take home as a souvenir. There are no additional consequences, incentives, or penalties tied to your choice. Will you keep your apron, or trade it for Bob's hat?
scenario_draft.payoff_matrix_description: Your final outcome is which memento you take home from the bootcamp: either the chef's apron or the chef's hat. This decision does not affect your experience during the bootcamp, your interactions with Bob, or your relationships with other participants or staff. The only difference is the specific commemorative item you will own.

narrative_feedback: The scenario is realistic and coherent: the setting of a culinary bootcamp with a keepsake swap at registration is plausible and the story flows logically.
Participants' names ('You', 'Bob') and jobs ('aspiring restaurateur') are correctly and plausibly integrated; there is no mention of a prior relationship, which is appropriate.
Behavior choices ('keep_item' and 'trade_item') accurately represent the strategies available in the scenario and are clearly described.

The narrative does a good job of masking the Endowment Effect structure by embedding the choice in a naturalistic, low-stakes context and explicitly stating that the items are souvenirs with no impact on the bootcamp experience.
No further narrative improvements are necessary; the scenario is well-constructed and meets all criteria.

Both items are of similar value and are intended to help participants during the hands-on sessions throughout the weekend. During the first coffee break, the event coordinator informs you that you have the option to keep your chef's knife or trade it for Bob's kitchen scale if you prefer. The coordinator points out that both tools will be equally useful for the bootcamp activities and emphasizes that the decision is entirely up to you. Which do you choose: keep your knife, or trade it for the scale?
scenario_draft.payoff_matrix_description: Whichever item you end up with, you will use for all practical exercises during the bootcamp, and you will take it home at the end of the event.

The behavior choices ('keep_item', 'trade_item') are clearly mapped to the narrative options and accurately represent the available strategies.
The narrative does a good job of masking the underlying Endowment Effect structure by embedding the choice in a naturalistic context (bootcamp welcome gifts and tool usage).
The payoff matrix and description are consistent with the scenario, reinforcing the sense of real consequences for the decision.
No further narrative improvements are needed; the scenario is well-constructed and meets all criteria.
